document.title: Texas Essential Knowledge and Skills for Science - Kindergarten

1CEF85004C3442DE9E0C5F9C3EDF99DB.description: identify ways that young plants resemble the parent plant.

ABE67A1E5FD641099FC3965F4B319662.description: identify and record the changes from seed, seedling, plant, flower, and fruit in a simple plant life cycle; and

4CB319C4B35549D3B93CEC92CD0414D4.description: identify the different structures that animals have that allow them to interact with their environment such as seeing, hearing, moving, and grasping objects;

D042AF1C730445518ADD967501D8B008.description: identify the structures of plants, including roots, stems, leaves, flowers, and fruits;

4E13D0D5B03B496FB0D1CBD1639DE692.description: The student knows that organisms resemble their parents and have structures and undergo processes that help them interact and survive within their environments. The student is expected to:

4D889E51810A45B19B10ACF4F28B0121.description: observe and identify the dependence of animals on air, water, food, space, and shelter.

CAB13AFC1D1A4317A99F6E41AA15361E.description: observe and identify the dependence of plants on air, sunlight, water, nutrients in the soil, and space to grow; and

3C533B74594B47D595AACED920FEA888.description: Organisms and environments. The student knows that plants and animals depend on the environment to meet their basic needs for survival. The student is expected to:

80A4D777A48D4469B9D6D5648DABDE97.description: The student knows that earth materials are important to everyday life. The student is expected to observe and generate examples of practical uses for rocks, soil, and water.

7DEA2F6327E14F71A215D5981A0C7E12.description: identify evidence that supports the idea that air is all around us and demonstrate that wind is moving air using items such as a windsock, pinwheel, or ribbon.

8169488A6D694F42B5E0376C1972D85A.description: observe and describe weather changes from day to day and over seasons; and

5879F4FCE6E34A82A6E62882DF0DFD12.description: describe and classify rocks by the observable properties of size, shape, color, and texture;

1E258DAE20C04FC5B35AAD89281641A8.description: The student knows that the natural world includes earth materials and systems that can be observed. The student is expected to:

85F6F6C3A00B419CB968AD9B493A6E42.description: observe, describe, and illustrate the Sun, Moon, stars, and objects in the sky such as clouds.

B032D73AB66D4A0C9310BDA369841B08.description: identify, describe, and predict the patterns of day and night and their observable characteristics; and

B053C7B8D81B4A5DAEBB50F067188403.description: The student knows that there are recognizable patterns in the natural world and among objects in the sky. The student is expected to:

B5A00BB3C3794BA4A83E1ED6C68FF6AC.description: demonstrate and explain that light travels through some objects and is blocked by other objects, creating shadows.

14B5AA4AE7084CDE87B11FAB82C1CED3.description: communicate the idea that objects can only be seen when a light source is present and compare the effects of different amounts of light on the appearance of objects; and

6E56F6A5B2C641B4A8DB56CF21654460.description: Force, motion, and energy. The student knows that energy is everywhere and can be observed in everyday life. The student is expected to:

05D15A98D51F463AA9AE68D8991AEB6A.description: Force, motion, and energy. The student knows that forces cause changes in motion and position in everyday life. The student is expected to describe and predict how a magnet interacts with various materials and how magnets can be used to push or pull.

C375942C8924422B89491C4627D91D04.description: The student knows that objects have physical properties that determine how they are described and classified. The student is expected to identify and record observable physical properties of objects, including shape, color, texture, and material, and generate ways to classify objects.

54D753D12EB040F19D50240C79AE326E.description: describe how factors or conditions can cause objects, organisms, and systems to either change or stay the same.

C3183B7C677E430A960F8A4C40E664A2.description: describe the relationship between the structure and function of objects, organisms, and systems; and

6A954601E4264E7CB11DCF48AD0A3E54.description: identify forms of energy and properties of matter;

5B198E73C4E24CDD906935621F6F153D.description: examine the parts of a whole to define or model a system;

762740F2066A4875920FCCB85C9A64D0.description: describe the properties of objects in terms of relative size (scale) and relative quantity;

30FCB6C0CFBB457D93A6C35ED1B2440C.description: investigate and predict cause-and-effect relationships in science;

934E9DFFEE344C90B16F2B805A3A6348.description: identify and use patterns to describe phenomena or design solutions;

7EDF1DA08082483A9119B7BF237F47EB.description: The student uses recurring themes and concepts to make connections across disciplines. The student is expected to:

C1350DD781C14641B803F15F08627930.description: identify scientists and engineers such as Isaac Newton, Mae Jemison, and Ynes Mexia and explore what different scientists and engineers do.

BA968407C57847A69F90B4B4D046C764.description: explain how science or an innovation can help others; and

89968F88B3A6478EA4D96583DDD4FE60.description: The student knows the contributions of scientists and recognizes the importance of scientific research and innovation on society. The student is expected to:

F7FA8570B1E9416A9964B8C02B0C9A4D.description: listen actively to others' explanations to identify important evidence and engage respectfully in scientific discussion.

80667BDCC2ED4A6D83F526198EBB2207.description: communicate explanations and solutions individually and collaboratively in a variety of settings and formats; and

E86CB62C48DB42D89DCFECD024DB2820.description: develop explanations and propose solutions supported by data and models;

38947EF993E84CC98A0185855F7723CA.description: The student develops evidence-based explanations and communicates findings, conclusions, and proposed solutions. The student is expected to:

1E1BAA9AF05C4075BEFC63BAB6C46087.description: evaluate a design or object using criteria to determine if it works as intended.

FF35025DD7D3491597797A9C1F6D1C53.description: use mathematical concepts to compare two objects with common attributes; and

82DDE5930CAE430393CE928903DCB2E2.description: analyze data by identifying significant features and patterns;

E5F3E13F1205493BA0A39E96CAC5FCB7.description: identify basic advantages and limitations of models such as their size, properties, and materials;

B39EAE4039884B01891B7411253FB47D.description: The student analyzes and interprets data to derive meaning, identify features and patterns, and discover relationships or correlations to develop evidence-based arguments or evaluate designs. The student is expected to:

5978C4E68D6D45B68C664EFDBF3A35CA.description: develop and use models to represent phenomena, objects, and processes or design a prototype for a solution to a problem.

570929ED7D3F456B8F91587AA49EC088.description: record and organize data using pictures, numbers, words, symbols, and simple graphs; and

CF6A5BAB341346E489A3BB7C3722E28D.description: collect observations and measurements as evidence;

C9EE4D0AD83D4F9CB2E3E0410D71CF86.description: use tools, including hand lenses, goggles, trays, cups, bowls, sieves or sifters, notebooks, terrariums, aquariums, samples (rocks, sand, soil, loam, gravel, clay, seeds, and plants), windsock, demonstration thermometer, rain gauge, straws, ribbons, non-standard measuring items, blocks or cubes, tuning fork, various flashlights, small paper cups, items that roll, noise makers, hot plate, opaque objects, transparent objects, foil pie pans, foil muffin cups, wax paper, Sun-Moon-Earth model, and plant life cycle model to observe, measure, test, and compare;

4674735506604538807C9DA2995320A0.description: identify, describe, and demonstrate safe practices during classroom and field investigations as outlined in Texas Education Agency-approved safety standards;

2D3A066940B547E9B65BA4ADCE586D9A.description: use scientific practices to plan and conduct simple descriptive investigations and use engineering practices to design solutions to problems;

61B68EFABD9A49B38DB5449D190D73F6.description: ask questions and define problems based on observations or information from text, phenomena, models, or investigations;

8797C8AD55A546C18EC028EF84C43B22.description: The student asks questions, identifies problems, and plans and safely conducts classroom, laboratory, and field investigations to answer questions, explain phenomena, or design solutions using appropriate tools and models. The student is expected to:
